entry.title: Combined summary - Swift Activation - CTV
entry.summary:
The Bitcoin community is currently debating the merits and potential risks of CheckTemplateVerify (CTV), a soft fork proposal aimed at introducing new functions such as output locking to specific templates. There are contrasting views on CTV's evolution from multi-signature setups, with concerns about centralization, complexity, and security issues. The need for rigorous testing and review is highlighted before transitioning from established protocols to newer ones.
There is an emphasis on cautious consensus rule changes within Bitcoin, advocating for comprehensive understanding and agreement on the benefits and minimized risks before implementing any updates. The discussion includes considerations for adding new opcodes to enhance proposals like CTV, despite skepticism around CTV's initial ambitions, perceived risks, and limited advantages due to its focus on coin covenants and restrictions.
Concerning CTV implementation, more development and proof-of-concept instances are needed, despite incentives like those offered by BIP Bounty. Issues such as misunderstandings about TXHASH and unclear activation methods have led to calls for postponing the activation timeline. Contributions to refine CTV and active participation in related GitHub issues are encouraged.
Moreover, there is a push to create a BIP 8 client with 'LOCKINONTIMEOUT' set to true, indicating a preferred strategy for activating changes on the Bitcoin network. The community is also urged to consider the trade-offs between different activation methods through accessible dialogue, as illustrated by a branch available at https://github.com/xbtactivation/bitcoin/tree/bip8-ctv.
Contrastingly, concerns are raised about misleading updates that offer miners discretionary power over CTV activation, with suggestions of implementing a User-Activated Soft Fork (URSF) to counter any deceptive signaling. This points to deep divisions among developers regarding updates, miner autonomy, and feature activation.
Furthermore, an update to CTV's activation parameters aims for simplicity and functionality, detailing start times, timeouts, and minimum activation heights. The role of CTV in supporting payment pools, vaults, and congestion control is underlined, with claims of greater Proof of Concept support than the Taproot upgrade. Advocates for these changes are advised to adopt the client by January 1, 2024, to prevent potential delays in activation until 2028. Secure communication via Proton Mail is utilized for these discussions.
